Why not view reality on a factually based rational analysis, instead of "narratives", i.e. fictional stories designed for political expediency? Let us examine the number of peace offers, proposals, gestures and opportunities the Arabs have rejected since 1920 - a pattern of 94 years - and ask the simple question: What is the common denominator for all these rejections, shall we?

1920, San Remo conference decisions, rejected

1922, League of Nations decisions, rejected

1937, Peel Commission proposal, rejected

1947, UN General Assembly proposal, rejected

1948, The State of Israel stretched out hand for peace, rejected

1967, The State of Israel stretched out hand for peace, rejected

1978, Begin/Saadat peace proposal, rejected

1995, Rabin's Contour-for-Peace, rejected

2000, Barak/Clinton peace offer, rejected

2005, Sharon's peace gesture, rejected

2008, Olmert/Bush peace offer, rejected

2009 to 2013 Netanjahu's invitation to peace talks, rejected

All of the above offers, proposals, gestures and opportunities implied the acceptance of the right of a sovereign nation-state of the Jewish people to be, to exist in part of the Jewish people's ancestral homeland. This acceptance of right is what at the core of achieving an accommodation of peaceful coexistence. Indeed, the Arabs object categorically to the right of a sovereign nation-state of the Jewish people to be, to exist on ANY parcel of land of this people's ancestral homeland which is the essence of the conflict.

NL Katz:  Absolutely none of the proposals made by Israel following 1967 would have resulted in a viable Palestinian state.  If the Israelis were serious about making peace on realistic terms they wouldn't continue to build settlements in the West Bank and/or East Jerusalem that they'd have to abandon once a Palestinian state were to be established in those "disputed" areas.  Unhappily, getting Israel to move in this direction is comparable to getting China to acknowledge that its occupation of Tibet is both illegal and immoral.

The Palestinians' desire "to join 15 international conventions and treaties...won't get them a state" for the very simple reason that the U.S. will dependably use its veto power at the U.N. to preclude that from happening.  It's clear that this country has done everything it possibly can to encourage Netanyahu and his Likudniks to forge a just peace resulting in a Palestinian state (i.e., one that would free them from accusations of apartheid).  All that's left for us to do is to stop trying to placate them by employing that veto.  This would, of course, require a level of, shall we say, chutzpah that no U.S. president has ever seemed to possess.  But come on, Mr. Obama- just do it anyway.  You can't run for office again, but you can send out word that every Democratic senator and congressman who's up for reelection (or not) can feel free to publicly denounce you on this move.  It's the right thing to do- just pretend that Netanyahu is Vladimir Putin and that you have a golden opportunity to tell him what he can do with himself.  For that matter you can pretend that the West Bank is Ukraine, or maybe Chechnya.  Not a great deal of imagination would be involved.

Dan, you probably should have known about all these costs when you bought your house.  But maybe not.  I'm president of an HOA that maintains a 2.4 ac common area for 29 homes.  It costs each homeowner $60/year.  It was $50 in 1994 and when it needed to be raised 8-9 homeowners voted against the $10 increase.  And still I have to harass at least 6 of them every year to pay, even under threat of a lien (for a whole $60!).  We do enforce a fence and recreational vehicle covenant too or half these people on a narrow cul-de-sac would have campers and boats parked all over.  I had to go to every open house for years when one of these 29 homes went up for sale to make sure the real estate agent told the buyers about the HOA.  For years many new buyers had no idea when that open space was next to their backyard.  They still wouldn't if the realtors and title companies "forgot" to tell them.  The homes sell for around $235k.

Tom and Tim both think it's impossible to tile a 12x12 square, and I think they're right.

Here's the list of possible rectangle sets with total area 144, found with the help of Mathematica.

(10x8, 7x4, 5x3, 6x2, 9x1)
(10x8, 6x4, 7x3, 5x2, 9x1)
(10x8, 6x4, 5x3, 9x2, 7x1)
(9x7, 10x4, 8x3, 6x2, 5x1)
(9x7, 8x6, 5x3, 4x2, 10x1)
(10x6,9x5, 8x3, 4x2, 7x1)
(9x6, 7x5, 8x4, 10x2, 3x1)
(8x6, 9x5, 7x4, 10x2, 3x1)
(8x6, 7x5, 10x4, 9x2, 3x1)

None of these sets of rectangles can tile a 12x12 square.

The first three solutions include a 10x8 rectangle, and a 10x8 rectangle within a 12x12 square leaves a 2x8 region. The narrow rectangles in these solutions aren't long enough to fill that region.

The next solution is impossible, because the 9x7 and 10x4 rectangles can't be placed without leaving a 1-unit wide region at least 7 units long, and the only available width-1 rectangle is 5 units long.

The next solution is impossible because the 9x7 and 8x6 rectangles can't both fit in a 12x12 square without overlapping.

In the next solution, placing the 10x6 rectangle leaves a 2x6 region, which none of the remaining rectangles can fill.

In the second and third solutions from the last, placing the two largest rectangles leaves a 1-unit wide region at least 4 units long, and the only width-1 rectangle available is just 3 units long.

Finally, in the last solution, there's no way to fit the three largest rectangles into the 12x12 square without their overlapping.

S B Lewis, there was a time when the private sector outstripped the public sector in perks, wages and benefits. That was lost with the WTO, GATT, NAFTA and deregulation that allowed monopoly formation and vulture capitalism. That is what destroyed private sector jobs and benefits.

As for the USPS, it was flush with success eight years ago, so profitable that it was considering an all-electric fleet of postal trucks. Then Congress bankrupted the Postal Service in 2006 when it passed the Postal Accountability Enhancement Act (PAEA), which mandated that the Postal Service would have to fully fund retiree health benefits for future retirees -- 75 years out. No agency had ever before or ever since been forced to do such a thing. This onerous, unnecessary requirement broke the back of the nation's oldest government agency.

And now conservatives have the gall to complain that the Post Office is losing money?? Have they no shame at all?

This is the mistake that most grates on me, and it is everywhere. In fact I rarely hear lie and lay and all their tense variants used correctly anymore. The words are admittedly confusing if you haven't heard them used correctly on an everyday basis so that they are just a natural part of the way you speak. It doesn't seem that too many people really care about reversing this slide into what feels to me like lazy, sloppy and imprecise usage--but it would be nice to come up with some easy-to-memorize sentences/songs that kids could learn in the early grades that might make the proper usage stick, e.g., "I'm gonna lay down my sword and shield and then lie down in the grass"; "yesterday I laid down my sword and shield and then lay down in the grass" etc.
And then there's sink-sank-sunk. Nobody says sank anymore.

We have an intolerance problem in the US. Period. I was once talking to a Jewish customer on the phone who assumed my surname, one shared by Jews too, gave him license to launch into a tirade about black people. We harbor too many senseless prejudices. Black people with "Jewish-sounding" names. Christians mistaken for Jews. Human beings being human. And there are too many armed racists stewing in hatred.

Thank you, Frank Bruni, for this column. I am a Jew, and it is clear to me that anti-Semitism continues to fester. My last name doesn't "sound Jewish" and I guess that I don't "look Jewish", because I occasionally encounter people who express anti-Semitic sentiments on the belief that I mus share them.

Even more disturbing are the anti-Semitic actions recently reported on college campuses, including the posting of mock eviction letters on the dorm room doors of Jewish students (or students with surnames presumed to be Jewish) and the desecration of public menorahs. (Such events have taken place at Northeastern University in Boston and at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, and elsewhere.)

The American Jewish community, sadly, is often far too complacent or perhaps timid with respect to confronting anti-Semitism. The abhorrent slayings in Kansas City a day before the Passover holiday are a tragic wake-up call. Anti-Semitism must be recognized, confronted and extinguished, ideally through interfaith efforts that show compassion and appreciation for those of all faiths.

Anti-Semitism is even more entrenched and deadly in other parts of the world. The murder of journalist Daniel Pearl in Pakistan is a case in point.

One more point: any type of racial, ethnic or religious prejudice is hateful. To recognize anti-Semitism is not to elevate it relative to other prejudices, but to bring it out of the shadows.

Again, my thanks to Frank Bruni for this column.

Just reread my post from earlier. Couple of silly typos -- the last row in the third and fourth rectangles should be 11, not 12.

I see someone has posted a couple of solutions for the 13 x 13 square. Here's at least an outline of the proof I had in mind for why it can't be done for a 12 x 12 square.

First, since the length of the side of the square is longer than the length of any of the rectangles, there must be at least two rectangles along each side of the square. Suppose that three rectangles are all on one side of the square, with different widths, say 3, 4 and 5. Since they all must have different lengths, too, there is no way to fill the remaining space in the square with only two more rectangles.

Therefore, the only way you can divide the square into five rectangles, where none of the lengths or widths match, is like the example I gave earlier, where four of the rectangles are arranged with their edges overlapping around the fifth rectangle, which touches none of the edges of the square.

For the 11 x 11 square, one of the rectangles touching the sides of the square had a width of only 1, which worked, because the rectangle with a length of 10 butted against it, and the combination completed one of the edges of the square. However, with a 12 x 12 square, the rectangle with a width of 1 cannot be on one of the edges, because it would take a rectangle with a length of 11 to complete one of the sides of the square, and our longest rectangle has a length of only 10.
Expectations are one thing--demands are another.

I've long thought the secret ingredient for raising successful children is expectations.  A difficult trait to describe and quantify, but you know it when you see it, and when you don't.   As a parent, I always resented being managed toward hyper involvement by school administrators who pushed so hard to force parental involvement.   And I can think of many parents who were constantly hovering in the schools, but were lacking that elusive ingredient of expectations.   Their outcomes range from mediocre to poor to disastrous.

You imply that the attitude shown by Spieth's statement "it's just a matter of time" is a bad one, but I think it is a good one because confidence is key. I think we can both agree that Tiger Woods is one the greatest golfers, if not the greatest, of all time. Watch any Tiger post-round interview and his demeanor is always positive and confident, always focusing his comments on what he did well. Now, when you see Tiger confidently surging down the final nine of a tournament, while others seem timid, it has much to do with his positives-focused approach. He is focused on what he does well, not letting the doubts of poor past performance cloud his head, just like he is when he makes statements in post-round interviews. Spieth saying, "it's just a matter of time" shows he will have his mind in the right place the next time he is on the final 9 of Augusta seeking his first green jacket. Instead of a mind clouted with doubt about his abilities, he will be over the ball thinking "it's just a matter of time," an approach that has proven successful for one of golf's all time greats.
